The ${\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}$ measurements for  ${\mathrm{e^- + e^+}}$, ${\mathrm{e^{\pm}+p}}$, and p($\bar{\mathrm{p}}$)+p collisions are shown in Fig.~\ref{Fig6}(a). 
They indicate a nonlinear increase with $\log({\sqrt{s}})$, with 
${\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}_{\mathrm{ee}} > {\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}_{\mathrm{pp}} > {\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}_{\mathrm{ep}}$ at each value of ${\sqrt{s}}$. 
In contrast, Fig.~\ref{Fig6}(b) shows a linear increase of  $[{\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}/{N_\mathrm{pp}}]^{1/3}$  (${N_\mathrm{pp}} =1$) 
with $\log({\sqrt{s}})$, suggesting a linear increase of $T$ with $\log({\sqrt{s}})$.  
Fig.~\ref{Fig6}(b) also indicates comparable slopes for  $[{\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}/{N_\mathrm{pp}}]^{1/3}$ vs. $\log({\sqrt{s}})$
for ${\mathrm{e^- + e^+}}$, ${\mathrm{e^{\pm}+p}}$, and p($\bar{\mathrm{p}}$)+p collisions, albeit with different magnitudes for $[{\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}/{N_\mathrm{pp}}]^{1/3}$. 
This similarity is compatible with the notion of an effective energy $E_\mathrm{eff}$ in  
p($\bar{\mathrm{p}}$)+p and ${\mathrm{e^{\pm}+p}}$ collisions, available for particle 
production \cite{Feinberg:1972ph,Albini:1975iu, Basile:1980ap,Basile:1981jz}. 
The remaining energy is associated with the leading particle/s which emerge 
at small angles with respect to the beam direction - the so-called leading particle effect \cite{Back:2003xk}. 
In a constituent quark picture~\cite{Nyiri:2002xb}, only a fraction of  the available quarks 
in p($\bar{\mathrm{p}}$)+p  and ${\mathrm{e^{\pm}+p}}$ collisions,  contribute to $E_\mathrm{eff}$. 
Thus,  ${\sqrt{s}}_{\mathrm{ee}} \approx \kappa_2{\sqrt{s}}_{\mathrm{pp}} \approx \kappa_3{\sqrt{s}}_{\mathrm{ep}}$ 
($\kappa_1 =1$)  would be expected to give similar values for $E_\mathrm{eff}$ \cite{Sarkisyan:2004vq} and  
hence, comparable ${\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}$ values in ${\mathrm{e^- + e^+}}$,  p($\bar{\mathrm{p}}$)+p and ${\mathrm{e^{\pm}+p}}$ collisions. 
Here, $\kappa_{2,3}$ are scale factors that are related to the number of quark participants and hence,
the fraction of the available c.m energy which contribute to particle production. 

Figure~\ref{Fig6}(c) validates this leading particle effect. It shows that the disparate magnitudes
of $[{\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}/{N_\mathrm{pp}}]^{1/3}$ vs. ${\sqrt{s}}$ for ${\mathrm{e^- + e^+}}$, p($\bar{\mathrm{p}}$)+p and ${\mathrm{e^{\pm}+p}}$ collisions (cf. Fig.~\ref{Fig6}(b))
scale to a single curve for $[{\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}/{N_\mathrm{pp}}]^{1/3}$ vs. $\kappa_n {\sqrt{s}}$
where $\kappa_1 = 1$, $\kappa_2 \sim 1/2$ and $\kappa_3 \sim 1/6$.


The values for $\kappa_{2,3}$ validate the important role of  quark participants
in p($\bar{\mathrm{p}}$)+p and ${\mathrm{e^{\pm}+p}}$ collisions. A fit to the data in Fig.~\ref{Fig6}(c) gives  the expression

which can be used to predict ${\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}$ as a function of ${\sqrt{s}}$, for ${\mathrm{e^- + e^+}}$, ${\mathrm{e^{\pm}+p}}$, and p($\bar{\mathrm{p}}$)+p collisions. 

Figures \ref{Fig1}(a) and  \ref{Fig2}(a) show ${\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{\eta \approx 0}$ measurements for inelastic (INE)
and non-single-diffractive (NSD)  p+p collisions (respectively) for beam energies spanning the range 
${\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}} \sim\unit{15}{\GeV}$~-~$ \unit{13}{\TeV}$; they indicate a monotonic 
increase of  ${\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{\eta \approx 0}$ with ${\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}}$ similar to that observed for ${\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}$ in Fig.~\ref{Fig6}(a). 
Figs.~\ref{Fig1}(b) and  \ref{Fig2}(b), by contrast, confirms the expected linear growth of  $[({\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{\eta \approx 0})/{N_\mathrm{npp}}]^{1/3}$ 
with $\log({\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}})$. The open points and dotted curves in these figures, affirm 
the expected trend for the ${\sqrt{s}}$ dependence of $[({\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{\eta \approx 0})/{N_\mathrm{qpp}}]^{1/3}$. Here, the change in magnitude largely
reflects the difference in the proportionality constants for ${N_\mathrm{npp}}$ and ${N_\mathrm{qpp}}$ ({\em i.e.}, ${N_\mathrm{pp}}^{1/3} \propto R$).

Here, it is noteworthy that the recent inelastic p+p measurements  at ${\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}} = \unit{13}{\TeV}$ 
by the CMS \cite{Khachatryan:2015jna} and  ALICE \cite{Adam:2015pza} collaborations  
are in very good agreement with the scaling prediction shown in Fig.~\ref{Fig1}(b). 
The data trends in Figs.~\ref{Fig6}(c), \ref{Fig1}(b) and \ref{Fig2}(b) also suggest 
that  the mean transverse momentum ($\left< p_T \right> \propto T$) for  the particles 
emitted in these collisions,  increase as $\log({\sqrt{s}})$.

The scaling properties for p+A and A+A(B) collisions are summarized in  Fig.~\ref{Fig3} where illustrative 
plots of  $[({\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{|\eta| = 0.5})/{N_\mathrm{npp}}]^{1/3}$ vs. ${{\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}}\eta}$ and ${N_\mathrm{npp}}^{1/3}$, 
and $[({\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{|\eta| = 0.5})/{N_\mathrm{qpp}}]^{1/3}$ vs. ${N_\mathrm{qpp}}^{1/3}$ are shown. 
Analogous plots were obtained for other collision systems and beam energies.
Figs.~\ref{Fig3}(a)  and \ref{Fig3}(b) show that, irrespective of the collision system, 
$[({\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{|\eta| = 0.5})/{N_\mathrm{npp}}]^{1/3}$ increases as $\log({{\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}}\eta})$ (${N_\mathrm{npp}}^{1/3}$),  
suggesting that $T$ has a logarithmic (linear) dependence on the pseudorapidity 
density (size) at a given  value of ${\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}}$; note the slope increase with beam energy,
as well as the lack of sensitivity to system type (Cu+Cu, Cu+Au, Au+Au, U+U), for a fixed 
value of ${\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}}$. These results suggest that, in addition to the expected increase with ${\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}}$, 
the mean transverse momentum $\left< p_T \right>$ or transverse mass $\left< m_T \right>$ of the 
emitted particles, should increase as $\log({{\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}}\eta})$ at a given value of ${\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}}$.



They also suggest that the pseudorapidity density factorizes into 
contributions which depend on ${\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}}$ and  ${N_\mathrm{npp}}^{1/3}$ respectively. 
Indeed, the data sets shown for each ${\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}}$ in Fig.~\ref{Fig3}(b), can be scaled 
to a single curve with scaling factors that are proportional to $\log({\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}})$.

Figure~\ref{Fig3}(c)  contrasts with Figs.~\ref{Fig3}(a) and \ref{Fig3}(b). It shows that,
when ${N_\mathrm{qpp}}$ is used instead of ${N_\mathrm{npp}}$,  the size dependence of $[({\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{|\eta| = 0.5})/{N_\mathrm{npp}}]^{1/3}$, 
apparent in Fig.~\ref{Fig3}(b), is suppressed  (but not its ${\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}}$ dependence).  
We attribute the flat dependence of $[({\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{|\eta| = 0.5})/{N_\mathrm{qpp}}]^{1/3}$ on size (${N_\mathrm{npp}}^{1/3}$ or ${N_\mathrm{qpp}}^{1/3}$), 
to the linear dependence of  $N_{\mathrm{qp}}/{N_\mathrm{npp}}$ on initial size as illustrated in 
Fig.~\ref{Fig4}(a) for Pb+Pb and Au+Au collisions. Note that for central and mid-central 
p+Pb collisions, $N_{\mathrm{qp}}/{N_\mathrm{npp}}$ decreases with ${N_\mathrm{npp}}^{1/3}$; this 
results in a reduction of the energy deposited in these collisions, as well as large multiplicity 
fluctuations.

The ${\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}}$ dependence of $[({\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{|\eta| = 0.5})/{N_\mathrm{qpp}}]^{1/3}$  for A+A(B) and  NSD p+p collisions  
are compared in Fig.~\ref{Fig4}(b). The comparison indicates strikingly similar trends  for NSD p+p, and A+A(B) 
collisions,  as would be expected for a common underlying particle production mechanism in these collisions. 
Note that for ${\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}} \lesssim 2$~TeV, higher temperatures [and larger $\left< p_T \right>$] are implied for the 
smaller p+p collision systems. Figs.~\ref{Fig3}(c)  and  \ref{Fig4}(b) also indicate that the centrality and ${\sqrt{s}}$ dependent 
values of ${\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{|\eta| = 0.5}$, obtained for different collision systems,  scale as ${N_\mathrm{qpp}}$ and $\log({\sqrt{s_{\mathrm{NN}}}})$. 
A fit to the A+A(B)  data in Fig.~\ref{Fig4}(b), gives the expression

\begin{eqnarray}

\begin{split}
{\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{|\eta| = 0.5} =   {N_\mathrm{qpp}} \left[ b_{\mathrm{AA}} + m_{\mathrm{AA}}\log({\sqrt{s}}) \right]^3 , \\
b_{\mathrm{AA}} = 0.530 \pm 0.008,\   m_{\mathrm{AA}}= 0.258 \pm 0.004, 
\end{split}

\label{eq5}
\end{eqnarray}











which systematizes the collision energy and centrality dependencies of the pseudorapidity density 
in A+A(B) collisions across the full range of beam energies.
Eq.~\ref{eq5} provides a basis for robust predictions of the value of ${\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{|\eta| = 0.5}$ as a function of ${N_\mathrm{qpp}}$ and ${\sqrt{s}}$ 
across systems and collision energies. For example, it predicts an $\sim 20$\% increase in the ${\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}} \eta|_{|\eta| = 0.5}$ values 
for Pb+Pb collisions (across centralities) at $\unit{5.02}{\TeV}$, compared to the same measurement 
at $\unit{2.76}{\TeV}$. This increase reflects the respective contributions linked to the increase   
in the value of  ${\sqrt{s}}$ and the small growth in the magnitudes of ${N_\mathrm{qpp}}$.

In summary, we have performed a systematic study of the scaling properties of ${{\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}}\eta}$ measurements for p+p, p+A and A+A(B) collisions, 
and ${\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}$ measurements for ${\mathrm{e^- + e^+}}$,  ${\mathrm{e^{\pm}+p}}$,  and p($\bar{\mathrm{p}}$)+p collisions, to investigate the 
mechanism for particle production in these collisions.
The wealth of the measurements, spanning several orders of magnitude in ${\sqrt{s}}$, indicate characteristic scaling 
patterns  for both ${{\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}}\eta}$ and ${\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}$, suggestive of a common underlying entropy production mechanism 
for these systems. The scaling patterns for ${\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}$ validate the essential role of the leading particle 
effect in p($\bar{\mathrm{p}}$)+p and ${\mathrm{e^{\pm}+p}}$ collisions and the importance of quark participants in A+A(B) collisions. 
The patterns for the scaled values of ${{\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}}\eta}$ and ${\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}$ indicate strikingly similar trends  for NSD p+p and 
A+A(B) collisions, and show that the pseudorapidity density and the ${\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}$ for ${\mathrm{e^- + e^+}}$,  ${\mathrm{e^{\pm}+p}}$, p+p, and 
A+A(B) collisions, factorize into contributions which depend on $\log({\sqrt{s}})$ and  ${N_\mathrm{pp}}$ respectively. 
The quantification of these scaling patterns, give expressions which serve to systematize the 
${{\mathrm{d}} N_\mathrm{ch}/{\mathrm{d}}\eta}$ and ${\langle N_\mathrm{ch} \rangle}$  measurements for ${\mathrm{e^- + e^+}}$,  ${\mathrm{e^{\pm}+p}}$,  p($\bar{\mathrm{p}}$)+p, p+A  and A+A(B) collisions, 
and to predict their magnitudes as a function of ${N_\mathrm{pp}}$ and ${\sqrt{s}}$. These scaling results have important utility in the 
study of a broad array of observables which are currently being pursued at both RHIC and the LHC.
